awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Elucidating the role of sigma-hole interactions in advanced functional materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Watkins at the University of Mississippi conducts research to gain a deeper understanding of how chemical structures and interactions between molecules affect the light absorbing and electronic properties of organic materials. This fundamental chemistry knowledge is important for the future design of functional materials for technological applications such as electronic and solar devices, which are ubiquitous in our daily lives. Moreover, the project provides research training to the next generation of scientists and engineers. Integrated with the CAREER plan are opportunities to increase the interests of young women and underrepresented minorities (URMs) in science by immersing high school seniors into a summer research program called Operation ICB (I Can Be). The program helps to increase the retention in STEM-related career fields via networking and extended mentorship.

The operational efficiency of organic electronic devices such as organic field effect transistors and organic photovoltaics depends not only on the molecular components but also on the supramolecular structure formed by the pi-conjugated molecules. The research focus of this CAREER project, which is jointly supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program and the EPSCoR Program of NSF, is to establish the foundation for utilizing halogen bonding between novel pi-conjugated molecules to form high-performing optoelectronic materials. This project aims to develop molecular design principles for controlling the self-organization of pi-conjugated molecules in nanoscale arrays and enhancing the light-harvesting and electronic properties of these assemblies.  This award increases the interest of young women and underrepresented minorities (URMs) in science by immersing high school seniors into a summer research program. The program also increases the retention of student in STEM-related career fields via networking and extended mentorship.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop a better understanding of how interactions between molecules contribute to their optical and electronic properties. As society moves toward more sustainable energy sources and investments, organic or carbon-based electronic materials have shown tremendous potential as low-cost, highly processible, and tunability alternatives to their inorganic counterparts. Key factors that contribute to the operational efficiency of these materials are the dimensionality or long-range order of molecules that comprise the material. This molecular arrangement is governed by weak noncovalent intermolecular interactions (e.g., van der Waals forces, pi-pi interactions, hydrogen bonds, and halogen bonds). The approach taken by the PI and her team involved optimizing halogen bonding interactions between pi-conjugated molecules (i.e., oligomers) to form high-performing materials. Despite its favorable attributes, halogen bonding is less studied and utilized in materials applications relative to other noncovalent interactions. Thus, with their work, they sought to develop new self-assembling molecules capable of forming complex molecular arrangements and study how variations in the assembly affect the photophysical and electronic properties of the resulting material.


Interdisciplinary collaborations between chemists, engineers, and theoreticians were established to complete this work. During the course of this project, over 15 oligomers and 4 conductive polymers were synthesized. Their morphologies, as well as optoelectronic properties, were explored to better understand the interplay between molecular architecture and functional performance. The NSF-funded project resulted in 8 peer-reviewed publications outlining the synthesis of these molecules, detailing spectroscopic and computational methodologies for identifying characteristic signatures of halogen bonding and showcasing their applicability in solar devices. The work aided in establishing guidelines/priority rules for halogen bonding in material design.


This project also contributed to the rigorous training and intellectual growth of 3 Ph.D. students and 4 undergraduate supporting researchers in laboratory techniques and science communication. In regard to broader impacts, primary efforts sought to increase the representation of women and minorities in STEM. Through the PI’s program, Operation ICB (I Can Be), 11 high school (HS) students were provided a four week-long summer laboratory research and collegiate experience. Participants in the program learned basic concepts of chemistry, structural diversity, instrumentation and techniques in organic chemistry, and communication in research reports and presentations. The HS students participated in lectures where professors from different departments discussed their research and career trajectory. In addition, students were provided campus room and board, exposing them to the collegiate environment and given advice on financial aid, entrance exam preparation, and networking. Of the 11 students, 8 pursued STEM degrees post-high school, 5 enrolled in southeast regional colleges/universities, and 1 completed post-graduate training in a STEM-related field.
